original: Gauthier was just 20 years old at the time. She also gave the American premieres of The Songs of Bilitis by Claude Debussy, Fugitive by Charles Ives, and Nocturne by Ernest MacMillan. During the 1920s, Gauthier's reputation as a recitalist of contemporary music continued to grow. In 1925, she made her American orchestral debut. Despite this success, Gauthier's health began to falter. She had long suffered from headaches, which in 1927 were diagnosed as epilepsy. After suffering an episode in 1931, she checked herself into Bellevue Hospital for treatment. While hospitalized, she married Dr. Friedrich Rosenthal, a neuroradiologist. Following her recovery, Gauthier continued to pursue her career. In 1933, she made her first appearance at New York's Carnegie Hall with pianist Frederic Wood. In 1935, she received a Juilliard Fellowship in honor of her work as a soloist. She gave her last public concert in the spring of 1936 at Carnegie Hall. She died from complications of cancer of the spine on March 18, 1937.

original:
The episode's title is an allusion to the 1999 film Office Space. Dwight Schrute (Rainn Wilson) is not pleased that he was not selected to replace Michael, believing that Michael put in a good recommendation for him. Though Deangelo's introduction goes smoothly, Michael becomes disturbed when Deangelo wants to make some changes, such as how Erin Hannon (Ellie Kemper) answers the phone. While Deangelo gets annoyed with Jim and Pam, he loves the antics of Andy, who has resorted to physical comedy when his jokes fall flat, getting to the point where he pours hot coffee on his pants and (at Deangelo's urging) eats soap; Andy tells the camera with dazed sadness that "this is my life now". Deangelo's popularity with the employees causes Michael to get jealous to the point where he passes out peanut butter sandwiches, despite Deangelo's peanut allergy. Deangelo then assembles the staff in the "multipurpose room", including Dwight, who learned from Gabe Lewis (Zach Woods) that Michael did not put in a recommendation and thus snubs Michael. Jim quietly tells Michael that he chose to resign his job and needs to come to terms with both that choice and the fact that life is going to go on at the office. Deangelo then steps out of his meeting and asks Michael for advice for how to run the meeting, saying that he is a good manager and Dunder Mifflin will not be the same without him. The two make up with a reverse hug, Deangelo telling him that he should start enjoying his retirement. Michael returns to his office while Deangelo conducts his meeting in the conference room. In another effort to impress Deangelo, Jim and Pam bring in Cece, to which Deangelo reacts positively. While they celebrate getting back on his good side, Deangelo reveals to the camera that he is in fact indifferent to Cece and was just being polite. The episode was written by co-executive producer Daniel Chun, his fourth writing credit of the series. The episode's title is an allusion to the 1999 film Office Space.

Select the correct answer. Which of the following statements would most likely be part of a discussion guide for an interview that is being conducted to explore a person’s opinion about which courses are offered on campus? -The interviewer will ask the interviewee to talk about each of their courses offered at the university. -The interviewer will ask the interviewee about the types of people they come in contact with in their courses. -The interviewer will ask the interviewee to talk about the details of a particular course, including the different topics that are covered and the types of assignments that students are given to complete. -The interviewer will ask the interviewee to talk about how much they enjoy their courses and how they help them to develop personally and professionally.

Complete the sentences below with words from the word bank. 1. The Queen of Spain, ________ her throne to a new _______ a half-century ago. be, passenger 2. A _______ just finished his first _______ and plans to graduate next spring. junior, semester 3. According to the general manager, your behavior is not acceptable. You should be _______ to the _______. apologize, meeting 4. If the general manager doesn’t agree with your proposal, you should be prepared to _______ the proposal to _______ the company’s lawyers. revise, executives 5. The government has promised to _______ cuts in funding to programs that are not _______ to the public interest. reduce, serving 6. I will try to _______ the grant application as soon as I get the money to pay for the typing. complete 7. The police chief _______ he was wrong to call the press about the case without _______ the other officers. admits, discussing 8. _______ from their plans to expand their businesses, the couple _______ the idea of buying a vacation home. Deciding, reconsidered 9. The speech made a big _______ on the mayor’s plans for urban renewal. impact 10. I hope you will be able to attend my lecture _______ time for our meeting next week. arrange 11. The President is _______ to meet with his cabinet about the budget proposal. scheduled 12. We have several _______ for the government contract. possibilities 13. She is _______ to become a medical doctor. devoting 14. They are working on a _____ design for the conference room. innovative 15. The new manager is _______ the changes in the system. implementing 16. I _______ looking at the new manager’s application before you discuss it at the meeting. have, considering

Imagine that you own a garden store and you need to find a way to market your store to a new community of gardeners. What techniques would you use to reach this new audience? What strategies would you use to encourage them to buy your products?

The characters work to solve the case, and Dunham becomes worried about the mental stability of the team's chief, Phillip Broyles (Lance Reddick). The episode was received favorably by critics.

Walter summons Peter to the Fringe office for a meeting. Peter and Olivia are in the car when Peter complains about a man singing, which Olivia disagrees with. However, she loses control of the car while driving. She takes Peter to the hospital, and he complains about the staff's treatment. Afterwards, Peter goes back to the Fringe office and investigates Walter's current case: a newborn baby has aged into an 80-year-old man. Olivia, Dr. Lester (Richard Clarke), and his two sons, Tyler (Chris Tavarez) and Paul (David Barrett), take Peter to the baby's home. Tyler initially welcomes the team before killing Paul and attempting to do the same to his mother. Olivia recognizes the house as a former army safehouse, and Broyles arrives to make an arrest. Tyler escapes the house.

Walter asks for help from David Robert Jones (Jared Harris), a man involved in the experiment that had previously caused Peter's birth. Jones reveals that he now uses genetics to allow Tyler to age rapidly, as it fits his "mission". He asks Tyler to do the same to other children, but Tyler refuses and commits suicide. Jones realizes Walter had set a trap for him. Peter says goodbye to Walter before leaving. Walter asks Broyles to begin treating Olivia's car problems with an exorcism, but Broyles refuses. Olivia and Peter encounter a man named Frank Stanton (Scott Lovelace), who reveals that he knows about Peter and Olivia's romance. While working to solve the case, Olivia finds evidence that a cult murdered all of the children to harvest their pituitary glands to put in the brain of one of their members. Broyles, concerned about Olivia, takes a polygraph test and realizes that he is being surveilled by the Bureau.

Peter says that he believes Walter when he says the experiment was not an accident. Olivia calls Broyles, who tells her he is going to make changes in their case, because she is involved. He then tells her to take some time off and go see a therapist. She takes the advice, and sees Stanton, who begins to give her an exorcism. She fakes a seizure, which tricks him into giving her the chance to stab him with his own knife. Meanwhile, Walter is conducting a human experiment on him, injecting him with chemicals from Walter's old lab that will regenerate his body. Stanton locks himself inside the lab and lights it on fire. Walter's experiment pays off, and he saves Walter's life.

An alternate ending to this episode was included in the Fringe: Complete First Season DVD and Blu-ray sets. In this alternate ending, Stanton is seen being treated for his wounds after he escaped from the lab. While he is being treated, Walter appears behind him and puts him to sleep. Walter then transfers part of his brain to Stanton's body, where he begins to feel memories of his previous life.

First broadcast in the United States on September 29, 2008, the second episode of Fringe was watched by an estimated 8.68 million viewers, and received a Nielsen rating of 3.4/9 in the 18-49 age group. It was seen by an estimated 5.7 million households and received a 3.2 rating in the 18-49 demographic with its repeat airing the following night. Reviewers found similarities with the Lost (2004–2010) series and commented that the episodes were "just ok". They were generally positive to the episode, though, saying that it provided more background and context to the show, and some commentators expressed an interest to follow the series.

John Noble in 2009, the episode is Noble's first appearance on Fringe

The premiere of the first episode of Fringe received a generally favorable response, so the producers of the show focused on improving certain elements in order to make the viewers want to continue watching the show. Pinkner, Kurtzman, and Orci explained that the second episode was focused on maintaining the show's appeal and introducing characters and giving the writers a chance to add more context to the show. The episode was the first episode in the first season to feature the serialized elements. Pinkner, Kurtzman, and Orci said they had originally been set on making Fringe a serial drama, but found that "it was too much too soon", so they decided to take a "step-by-step approach to the serial elements of the show".

Alex Kurtzman, one of the executive producers of Fringe, said that while the pilot had focused on a large cast of characters, "The Same Old Story" would focus on the three main characters in the Fringe division. Kurtzman said he, Orci, and Pinkner wanted to portray Walter as a "mad scientist who clearly loves his family, and we wanted to kind of present a man who's both brilliant and vulnerable". They also said that while Olivia was a skilled agent, she would not be "the action hero" of the show. Kurtzman also said the third regular character, Peter, would serve as a window to Fringe division for the audience.

Orci said that it was decided to focus on the three main characters because he believed that television had gone through a time where large casts of characters were used, and "there is less risk involved when you are telling the audience that this is the core group and we'll see the others every so often". Fringe co-creator Abrams said the production staff wanted to develop a cast that viewers would like, and that the show would appeal to a mass audience rather than a niche audience. He also said that he sought to make the show as accessible as possible. Pinkner said the writers tried to find "a middle ground" between a serialized drama and the crime procedural, so the show would be easier to follow, while still "trying to create a mythology". Pinkner, Kurtzman, and Orci said that they sought to make the show's mythology evident for the audience, so they would be aware of what is occurring on the show, and avoid situations where they would be confused about the show's background, and whether it would have a strong narrative drive. In the end, Pinkner said, "it's just a matter of having a cast that people can grow to care about and a mythos that's mysterious and interesting and is asked in the proper way". Orci said that the show's characters would serve as a window for the audience to view the show's mythology, because the audience's interest would be piqued when they discover more about the characters.

Laurie Pearlman, a writer and editor for The A.V. Club, found the episode reminiscent of Lost, a popular television show that was known for its complex mythologies and relationship-driven storytelling. Jim Slotek of Jam! noted that the episode had much in common with the pilot, including the same time the episode aired on and a plot line that had similarities with the pilot's. He said that the similarities made him believe that it was the writers' intent that viewers would watch the pilot before the second episode. Slotek also said the episode failed to add more complexity to the show's mythology. Daniel Bet

An uptempo dance song, Sorry was one of the first tracks developed for the album. One remix on the CD maxi single was done by the Pet Shop Boys, featuring added lyrics by the band. The song features a dance groove tempo, and talks about personal empowerment and self-sufficiency. Sorry received positive reviews from contemporary critics, who declared the track the strongest song on Confessions on a Dance Floor. Some critics also commented on the song's disco-influenced beats while comparing it to Madonna's older dance songs. It achieved commercial success, topping the singles charts in Italy, Spain, Romania and the United Kingdom, where it became Madonna's twelfth number one single. Sorry also reached the top 10 in several countries, including Austria, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, and Sweden. It appeared on numerous year-end critics' lists for 2006.

 The music video for Sorry was directed by Jamie King, and filmed in Las Vegas, Nevada in early February 2006. It portrays Madonna dancing and performing choreography alongside female dancers dressed in black leotards with cut-out patterns. The music video has been nominated for Best Dance Video and Best Female Video at the 2006 MTV Video Music Awards. Sorry has also been included in the set list of the Confessions Tour and Sticky & Sweet Tour, which featured elaborate dance routines. Sorry has also been a part of several compilation albums, including Hits One and Playlist: The Very Best of Madonna. In November 2017, Madonna re-released Sorry as a digital single and a music video for the new version was released on her official YouTube channel, two weeks later. The new version of the song features a production by Charlie Puth.

The Australian contribution to the Iraq War has been criticised by some; former Governor-General Bill Hayden said in 2004: "Australia will never again be viewed as a place of decency by the world." This sentiment was echoed by Bob Carr, former Premier of New South Wales, who declared, "I want the Australian flag removed from all military vehicles. I never want to see it again." In response, then-Defence Minister Robert Hill described these comments as "outrageous" and "un-Australian", while Prime Minister John Howard defended Australia's role in the conflict and denied it was in breach of the UN Charter or Australia's obligations under the Geneva Convention. Anti-war protests took place in major cities and included the public denunciation of the Australian Government by celebrity peace activist Bob Brown.

Later that year, Air Vice Marshal T. L. Grogan, the Air Force's chief of staff, took over as Commander-in-Chief, Australia, and Headlam succeeded Grogan as chief of staff on 3 July 1954.

He became Commander-in-Chief in 1959, relinquishing his post on 11 August 1960.

After his retirement, Headlam was actively involved in veteran affairs, serving as a committee member of the Department of Veterans' Affairs Advisory Committee, the Returned Services League's (RSL) National Council and State Congress, the War Service Homes Board and the Victorian RSL.

Headlam died on 1 September 1973 in the Alfred Hospital, Melbourne. He was buried in Eltham Cemetery, Eltham, Victoria, in the Forecourt section of the cemetery.

Headlam married Joy Mollie Owen in August 1940. They had two sons and a daughter. Headlam was survived by his wife, and sons Peter and Ken.

original: Every year, theatre-goers attend MTL's annual Festival of Music and Drama. The Meridian Symphony Orchestra (MSO), the oldest performing arts organization in the city, also participates in the annual Festival, and performs annually in the 1,000 seat Riley Center, which opened in 2006. The MSO, founded in 1974, has been a major part of the arts scene in Meridian and east central Mississippi since it began. The Symphony, now celebrating its 35th Anniversary Season, performs six classical concerts, two POPS concerts, and one Summer Sizzle concert annually. One of the most prestigious positions held by the Symphony is the Robert Ray Memorial Concerto Competition, which has helped aspiring young musicians throughout the area for the past 27 years. Hundreds of young musicians apply each year, and the winner is awarded a $1000 scholarship and has the opportunity to perform with the MSO. One of the most prominent black community organizations in Meridian, the local chapter of the NAACP, was started by C.B. Greenwood and other African-American civil rights leaders in 1918, before the national NAACP organization had officially been established. The chapter has continued to operate for over 95 years, and in 2010 began a new focus on voter registration and social equality.

If the material is not a semiconductor, then the electrical conductivity has little meaning; in the case of conductors, it can be assumed to be infinite, and the resistivity is almost zero. Semiconductors are insulators whose conductivity increases with increasing temperature, while the conductivity of conductors (metals) usually decreases with increasing temperature.

In any electrical conductor, all available charge carriers will be used when the temperature is sufficiently high and the electric field is sufficiently strong. The charge carriers have thermal energy, which causes them to randomly move around the material and get hot when they are trapped in an electric field. This is because their charge does not change, so they cannot emit or absorb heat. When the temperature is high enough, the charge carriers can get hot enough to move around in the material without colliding with other atoms or molecules.

A useful concept for electrical conduction is the electron-electron collision time (CCT) or collision time constant (CT). This is the time it takes for an electron to collide with another electron in the same direction, or in the opposite direction if it is traveling parallel to the field. This time depends on the field and the temperature. In the absence of external fields, the electron-electron collision time is equal to the time between collisions in the same direction.

The electron-electron collision time depends on the number of electrons in the material, so that more electrons lead to more collisions. For example, if a semiconductor has a single conduction band, then the electron-electron collision time is proportional to the number of electrons in the band. In the case of semiconductors, a greater concentration of electrons leads to a greater electron-electron collision time and therefore a greater electron drift velocity.

In an ideal metal, the electron-electron collision time is constant for all electrons. This is not true for most semiconductors because electrons in different conduction bands may have different collision times. For example, electrons in the same conduction band may have different collision times if the temperature is low enough, while electrons in the same conduction band may have different collision times if the temperature is high enough.

The electrical conductivity of a material is related to the temperature and electric field. When the temperature increases, the electron-electron collision time increases, so the conductivity increases. If the temperature decreases, the electron-electron collision time decreases, so the conductivity decreases.

Conductivity increases with temperature because electrons can get hot enough to move around in the material without colliding with other atoms or molecules. This is true even when the electric field is weak enough that electrons do not get hot enough to move around in the material.

For example, a metal like copper has a very large number of electrons, so when the temperature is high enough, it can get hot enough to move around in the material without colliding with other atoms or molecules. When the temperature decreases, the conductivity decreases because the electrons do not get hot enough to move around in the material without colliding with other atoms or molecules.

Upon its 2011 release, Portal 2 received critical acclaim and was nominated for a multitude of awards, including the Game Developers Choice Awards and the British Academy of Film and Television Arts Games Awards, and was one of the top ten best-selling games of 2011. It won several Game of the Year awards, including those from IGN, the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences, and the National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers. A major expansion, Portal 2: Lab Rat, was released as a prequel on April 19, 2012. It was originally published in print and was made available for download free of charge on the PlayStation Network, Xbox Live, and Steam. On May 4, 2012, Half-Life 2: Raising the Bar, a book that included part of the script for Portal 2, was released in paperback. It features further work by Ferrett, including a second plot guide. The PC version of the game features facial animation created by Gearbox using the Havok Behavior system. The game's soundtrack was composed and performed by veteran video game musician Mike Morasky. In addition to a full orchestral score for the single-player campaign, he also composed electronic songs for the soundtrack, which include vocals. In May 2012, the full single-player soundtrack was released on vinyl and CD by Square Enix's record label, e-Capcom, in a special release bundle. The music was also made available for digital download on Steam. The game also features music by Jonathan Coulton, who performed two original songs for the game, "Want You Gone" and "The Weight of the World". The game also features music by Valve musician Zack Paradis. Portal 2 received two Best Music Soundtrack nominations at the 2012 British Academy Games Awards.

The first to respond was a Spitfire belonging to the Rhodesian Air Force and operated by the Central Auxiliary Air Force squadron, flown by Captain Paul Fatti, a 24-year-old Rhodesian of Italian and English descent. Another Rhodesian Air Force helicopter also attempted to reach the area, but was damaged by a single bullet fired from a ZIPRA ground crew team. Despite this, the Rhodesian helicopter pilot still managed to come close enough to see Flight 825 crash, and to capture it on film. At 17:12 Captain Fatti was flying directly behind the Hunyani and took up a position of escort in the hope of being able to render assistance. The aircraft was low enough to see the faces of the passengers. Some of them had become hysterical as the aircraft pitched and yawed, throwing them about the cabin. As the Hunyani reached the ground, one of its propeller blades was ripped off by the treetops. Although it had come to rest on its port wing, the Hunyani was still descending. At 17:15, the fully fuelled aircraft hit the Zambezi riverbank, penetrated the topsoil and collided with two large Zambezi teak trees. The majority of passengers and crew survived the initial impact, although the wingtip hit one of the trees, throwing them into a further spin. The aircraft's port wing was cut off, and the fuselage began to detach from the port engine. The debris impacted on an area of the riverbank consisting of medium-sized granite boulders and some teak trees. Some of the passengers and crew members were thrown from the aircraft in this impact, while the rear part of the fuselage broke free. The forward section, including the cockpit, remained attached to the surviving engine, and continued to hurtle over the boulders. The engine began to ingest small rocks from the ground, and after a few seconds it also disintegrated. The cockpit was forced to land on a large boulder. The rear section of the fuselage was now detached from the fuselage and was travelling at speed down the slope of the riverbank. Eventually it hit the riverbank at an angle, hitting the ground and bursting into flames. A Rhodesian Air Force helicopter pilot, David Amsford, was able to reach the crash site from Umfuli, and landed his aircraft at the edge of the riverbank, and arrived at the scene at 17:21. He reported that a large number of survivors were still alive, many of them in pain. He said, "There were about 30 casualties on the ground and some of them were badly burnt." He began to administer aid to the survivors, who were visibly in shock. When Rhodesian forces began to arrive on the scene, some of the survivors clung to the survivors' hopes. "I'll survive because I'm so young and fit," one man stated. The following facts also suggest that the victims of Flight 825 were totally oblivious as to the state of their aircraft as it began its final descent.

1. When Flight 825's starboard wing was shot off it began to shake wildly from side to side.
2. When the Hunyani hit the trees the plane's fuselage began to spin so violently that the passengers and crew were thrown about the cabin.
3. It was not until the wing tip hit a tree that Flight 825 burst into flames.

These details, when compared to the eye witness accounts of Paul Fatti, Garth Beaumont and David Amsford, indicate that there were a total of three detonations when Flight 825 was attacked. The first detonation was that of a rocket-propelled grenade (RPG), fired at the aircraft while it was still in the climb phase of its flight. This hit the aircraft's starboard wing, causing it to shake from side to side and sending the aircraft into a spin. The second detonation came shortly after the first, when the heat-seeking missile hit the Hunyani, causing an explosion that could not be extinguished, and destroying the starboard wing and causing a massive fire. The third detonation, the most destructive of all, occurred when the aircraft's port wing tip hit the trees. The impact, together with the fact that the wing tip had been ripped off by the treetops and was now missing, combined to cause the Hunyani to burst into flames.
